reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a top down roguelike, this game will kill you over and over again to begin with. But be paintent, the game will reward you immensley with a lot of fun and characters. The more you die, the more characters and items drops you unlock.

The classic pixel art works really well in the top down view. The game play is very simple. You play with a mouse, and that's it. Turn based movement/actions makes this perfect for playing with a trackpad on a laptop too.

There is a nice compare" feature here which makes picking and choosing what equipment to use easier than most games I've played previously. Plenty of different classes

reviewText:
This game is not worth the time or money spent to play it.

There is absolutely no progression in the game save for what you find. There is no leveling, there is only loot. Of course, to get such loot you need to find it, off enemies, or out of barrels and chests. But, good luck surviving long enough to actually get it! In this game you have absolutely no passive regeneration. HP has to be restored through use of items and only through that.

In terms of mechanics, there's moving, attacking, and looting. Moving is really the one part I can't complain about, since well, you move just fine. Attacking is either ranged or melee, but regardless of range you will spend most of combat missing. You will miss much more than you ever hit. Now, with looting, there's one large thing that stands out: you don't have an inventory. You only have what you currently have equiped, and that's all. Want to save that potion for later? Nope, you have to use it now! This also means that looting devolves solely into: is this better or worse than what I have right now?" And potions are only for chugging on sight.

Generally speaking
date: a game such as this has some sort of scaling difficulty. Either the lower/higher the floor
recommended: the more difficult things get. Or you find something like Risk of Rain
hoursPlayed: where the longer you spend in game
voteText: the more difficult it gets. This game? There is no difficulty. There is only the RNG. Add to the fact that the floors are absolutely tiny
helpfulPercent:
and I hope you like get swarmed if you're unlucky.

This game is overly random and gives you no tools with which to determine your fate. This game is simply an overpriced RNG that looks like a rogue-like. Look elsewhere for a good rogue-like.

reviewText:
Despite its charmingly minimalist presentation, Hack, Slash, Loot takes simplicity a bit too far, resulting in a game where player choice carries exceedingly little weight against the overwhelming tides of chance.

Presented as a simplification of the Roguelike genre, Hack, Slash, Loot endeavors to be a casual, bite-sized dose of turn-based dungeon crawling goodness. Toning things down from more classical entries to the series like NetHack or the more recent Dungeons of Dredmor, players are relieved of such responsibilities as developing character skills, managing an inventory, or generally deciding what action to take at any given time, provided those actions might have been anything other than moving in a particular cardinal direction or performing a generic attack on an enemy.

The final product is a game where painstakingly small decisions such as what equipment you've chosen to pick up and wear will be most input the player has on each adventure's outcome, and even then, it won't quite measure up to the significance of what items and enemies the game decided to spawn in the first place.

Ultimately, the prognosis for each freshly-rolled adventurer is about the same as in any other hardcore roguelike- anything but the most carefully chosen actions will invariably end in your character's death, and odds are the right choices will still probably see you winding up dead sooner or later anyway. The difference between the two is that in a deeper Roguelike experience, you will likely have had more than a few memorable close calls where gambling on an unconventional action pays off in a few minutes of continued survival, or enjoyed the unique experience of mixing and matching talents to come up with a wholly one-of-a-kind adventurer whose inevitable death was a mere period a the end of an entirely unexpected story. In contrast, Hack, Slash, Loot will take every bit as much persistence and consideration to advance in, while completely failing to pay off in any sort of fun factor beyond trading genericized blows with enemies and crossing your fingers that the sword you found in the previous room will give you enough of a numerical advantage to be the last man standing.

To put it simply, Hack, Slash, Loot mistakes simplified graphics and gameplay for a pleasingly simplified gaming experience, while instead only succeeding in creating a dreadfully boring one that actively resists being played in a remotely engaging way compared to the sorts of games it seeks to emulate.

The final nail in the coffin is the pricetag, which at the time of this review exceeds vastly more playable and equally casual-friendly Steam roguelikes such as Dungeons of Dredmor and Tales of Maj'eyal, either of which is perfectly content to kill you every bit as quickly, while affording a comparatively staggering array of options with which to actually enjoy your brief life.

The bottom line is that fans of the genre and newcomers alike will do well to look elsewhere. Hack, Slash, Loot may be charming to look at, but there's barely a game here to play, and it just isn't worth the time.

reviewText: Hack Slash Loot is great fun. A rougelike-like, dungeon crawling RPG game, with a cutie pixel-art graphics style, and challenging gameplay. It's a turn based game, where each time you move on a tile, you along with everything else in the dungeon takes a turn, and you go through the dungeon completing quests. At the main menu you'll pick a character/class, each which have their own stats and unique style of play (melee, magic, ranged, etc) and depending on the quest, some may be better than others. You also choose the quest you want to play from the main menu, and each has its own story. But everytime you play one of these quests, the dungeon is different, since they're procedurally generated. (Though depending on the quest, they'll follow a certain blueprint". For instance
date: a quest that takes place in a large tower will always have a circular shaped map/dungeon). Fun
voteText: HSL is a great way to spend a half an hour or so."

Pretty fun, pretty nice.

Have you ever heard of a rogue-like? Well, they're wonderful little games chock full of complexity, instant-death, and general pandering to a small niche of gamers that just love them. reviewText:
I have played a good deal more than 2 hours of this game, probably about 5 or 6. Steam hasn't tracked all of my time of it for some reason, though I did play a lot offline in the summer.

I love this game, it's a good timewaster, I've had sessions that last 10 minutes and I die and that's totally satisfactory and I move on (or was just looking to waste 10 minutes).

I've only ever beaten one of the scenarios but I keep finding myself coming back to it. From what I hear there are a ton of unlockable classes and I should play more. I don't play a lot of roguelikes though, I'm surprised I'm as into this as I am.

The music is (kind of MIDI-y and) very reminiscent of some other games I love (title screen reminds me of Castle Crashers, dungeon themes remind me of Zelda) and serves the game well. The sound effects are minimalistic but follow the 8bit style. I love the UI, very functional.

I bought this game at full price, I'm not even sure why as most of my library is Humble stuff and sale stuff. I still recommend it at full price, though I hope it appears on Humble someday so it can get the exposure it deserves.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot reminds me a lot of how the old ASCII Nethack plays. It is at its core exceptionally brutal, however surprisingly enjoyable. Much of the games drops are out of your control and left to the dice (random number generator) which can either be in your favor or not. You must use doors and hallways to your advantage to limit monsters' ability to get swings on you which will greatly increase the odds in your favor. It is as close to a classic in terms of atmosphere and feel as you can get. It will not hold your hand, It will not give you tips or hints, It will do its best to kill you.

I've nearly clocked twenty hours and I have thus far died fifty five times with only four victories.

Highly recommended if you don't mind a challenge

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game. This game does not feel like a completed product.

Audio
This game lacks music. Most of your gameplay is filled with digital squeeks and sfx of the character's actions. The sounds get monotonous and boring.

Gameplay
This game is not repetitive for a dungeon crawler. This is good. The game was enjoyable for the first few hours. However, you'll realize that the randomly generated maps are at times impossible to complete. For example, you start a new game, and you spawn right next to a hobgoblin. You'll die. You won't be able to kill it, not with getting artifacts. The chances of getting artifacts are very low, considering that you'll have much more difficulty in trying to survive the first level, let alone trying to find artifacts.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a game that I got as part of a bundle, that I dearly wish had never been redeemed. Its presence, forever a taint on my library.

Avoid this game, for this game is precision crafted to avoid literally everything good about roguelikes ever. Hack, Slash, Loot is such a bad roguelike that it can be considered the anti-roguelike, the embodiment of all the bad parts of roguelikes with none of the good whatsoever.

The game lacks any sort of mechanical depth whatsoever. Everything boils down to boring, static numbers. Where a better roguelike would have classes that play differently, different skills perhaps, equipment preferences and the like, the ability to use magic perhaps, this game has none of those things. And I'm not saying that a roguelike has to have those things, you understand. I'm saying that most fantasy roguelikes would have those things, for instance Dungeons of Dredmor and Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup. Even within the Roguelite" games
date: you'd have characters with a vastly different playstyle resulting from different skillsets
hoursPlayed: like in The Binding of Isaac
voteText: Risk of Rain
helpfulPercent: Nuclear Throne
votesTotal: the list goes on.\n\nHack
votesFunny: Slash
commentsCount: Loot instead has classes that boil down to melee and ranged
column16: no resting to regain your health
column17: no skills
column18: no mana. Your character is simply a walking sheet of stats
column19: bolstered by your equipment that are nothing but stats. This creates no interesting gameplay choices
column20: either you find something that has better stats than your current equipment
column21: or you don't. There is no strategy
column22: there is no way to build your character
column23: there is no game to be enjoyed here.\n\nThis creates a game that is nothing but dice rolls upon dice rolls
column24: with little to no player input involved. There is no feeling of accomplishment if you get further than you previously did
column25: there is no anguish when you die. You cannot self reflect on a defeat that was entirely out of your control
column26: you cannot ask yourself what you could've done better.\n\nThe beauty of a roguelike is its nigh infinite replayability
column27: the ways you can experiment with builds
column28: the magic of discovery as you find something that works
column29: figure out the tricks of the game
column30: and get further everytime. The excitement when you turn a bad run around after an item that perfectly synergizes with your current character appears
column33: even perhaps to the final level
column34: before dying. Lamenting that you would've won if you had the right items. And what about the times when you pull through a bad run? That is the core of the roguelike experience that Hack
column36: Loot ultimately fails to capture.\n\nIn conclusion
column39: Loot is a thoroughly incompetent roguelike that tries to distill the experience
column40: but what you instead get is a shallow game with no identity
column41: no soul. It is a bad game
column43: and you should avoid it like the plague."

reviewText:
I realize many people give this game ALOT of flak, and I can understand why. The game is very much random in how things play out, and people often hate that.

I find the complete randomness to be very enjoyable, and makes every turn a tense, though fun turn of events!

The game can be unforgiving, but a real dungeon experience would be difficult if one was in such a situation, right?

All the negative reviews on that pop up when you 1st look up this game will deter alot of people I think. That's not fair to me. Especially at the current $7.00 price tag, this game should not be passed up.


- The game is difficult, it can be rough and unforgiving, but you get a CHALLENGE nonetheless! Doing well on a run when you know the odds can be against you? That's a truely gratifying experience. You're not really breaking your wallet on this one.

Don't let all the negative comments push you away, consider this game! Cheers!

reviewText:
Is this game too random?

Brogue, Dragon Age, Risk of Rain, ToME, Realm of the Mad God, Binding of Isaac, Spelunky, Minecraft... I could sit here and try to name many more games, all of which use random elements. In some your attacks always hit as long as you aim it right. Usually though it is based on chance whether you hit somebody or not, and how much damage you do. To improve your chances you improve your stats. Nearly all games rely on random elements such as item drops, enemy spawning, and more. This one just puts it more up front and in your face than most others.

You didn't always get your way in Nethack, or any of the older roguelikes. The same can be said for any new RPG, roguelike, or a mix of both, such as Spelunky or Binding of Isaac. You had to keep going, and hope that you got lucky enough for good items, easy enemies, a good floor layout, etc. You strategized what to do from there, based on what the game decided to throw at you. The only thing I feel it really needs would probably have to be longer chapters/areas, the ability to continue going on after defeating a boss, or some sort of infinite dungeon.

In my opinion I think that, while it does need improvements, tweaks, and hopefully more content, this game offers a view to the more classic idea of roguelikes. I'm definitely keeping my eye on this one.

( I play this DRM free and not on steam, hence the low play time. )

reviewText:
Pros:
- It was just over a dollar on the Humble Bundle store
- Nice art style
- Some decent gameplay concepts, like friendly NPCs that will fight alongside you
- Simple, responsive mouse controls

Cons:
- No inventory, WTF?
- NO SAVE FEATURE?!?!?!?
- Interface isn't well defined, could use some minor tweaks
- Extremely limited character class selection
- Nearly impossible to find healing items
- No apparent experience/leveling system

Overall:
I want to like this game, as I like the concept, and I find the controls to be extremely fluid and intuitive, but there are just so many basic things that this game is missing. I would play the living crap out of this if they introduced a proper inventory and leveling system, as well as the ability to save your game. It's sad to see such wasted potential.

reviewText:
I've spent quite a few hours playing this game off steam and only got it there for the cards. It's bad, really bad.

It's not just hard, it's unfair. There are so many misses you'll often be bored to tears looking at a whiff-fest. There are very few choices to make and even less that matter. Skill plays little role (and is utterly negligible compared to random luck) and I have found no depth whatsoever in this.

I haven't had a single minute or moment of fun in this game, ever. I don't know why someone would want to play it. I may have missed something, but if you have to search for more than 4 hours then there's a big problem with the game.

reviewText: There is no depth, skill, or strategy to this roguelike, just luck.\n\nYou can't get anything higher than a 60% hit chance at the start of the game, so expect to continuously whiff 4 times in a row. You can't heal from anything other than potions (you can't rest) so whether or not you have health at all is pure randomness. There's very little in-game instruction, so it's good that the mechanics are easy to understand, but that also means that you quickly realize how unfairly stacked against you the odds are. There are literally dozens of better games in the genre than this one.

reviewText:
I recommend this game with a bit of a warning. It can be fun, but only if you're extremely patient and don't mind having your ♥♥♥ handed to you every ten minutes or less.

It's a simple enough premise. Choose your mission. Choose your character. Go through the dungeon floors to try and complete your mission. Die. Try again. It's your typical roguelike in that regard. However, there is one thing that really makes this game more difficult than other roguelike dungeon crawlers such as Legend of Dungeon or even The Binding of Isaac (I know it's a bit of an odd comparison). The hit rate system in this game is seriously flawed. Your hit rate automatically starts out at roughly 60% regardless of what character you start with. You can deal a fair amount of damage and kill enemies in one hit, which is nice. Yet, you only hit them a fraction of the time and you can find yourself exchanging blows with a single enemy for two or three minutes until one of you dies. If you're surrounded by multiple enemies, odds are, you're going to die because you have such a small chance of killing them all before they've managed to kill you.

Luck based elements in roguelike games are not unheard of. Quite the opposite. They're a crucial part of the genre. However, when it becomes TOO luck based, it becomes a problem. Random level, enemy and item generation is a good idea. Random hit rates however are not. It makes completing a single floor almost impossible, let alone a whole mission. If you're patient enough to actually sit through countless runs of this game to beat a mission, then this is the game for you. However, if you do not like the idea of huge maps with a flawed probability driven combat system, then I would recommend other roguelike titles first.

reviewText:
This Game is honestly a bit of a dissapointment (probably more so if you got it for full price, I got it from a humble bundle). It looks like it should be a nice game, and while it does have its charm, but just not enough to make up for its flaws.

PROS:
-A number of artifacts, once you find one, you can choose to start with that artifact in any future game.
-A nice weapon/armor material system, silver weapons disarm foes, gold weapons give you stat bonuses occasionally, psychic weapons causes stat drain, among other things
-A couple of nice references to other (better) games in the form of some artifacts and uncommon rooms (such as an Aperture test chamber and I'm pretty sure I saw the castle crashers knights once)
-Despite not having an inventory (kind of a good thing, to be honest-it leads to less of the hoarding mentality many RPGs end up with) it does have a secondary weapon slot, and you can switch between the two easily, which I thought was a nice little feature.

CONS:
-Melee is awful-seriously, there's almost no reason to use it.
-combat is dull and repetetive (there's literally nothing beyond 'attack' and 'move')
-more than one or two friendly NPCs completely bog down the pace of the game
-Unlocking more characters seems to be completely random
-Death is frequent, not because the game is hard, but because healing is almost exclusively availible from random potions/scrolls/food (and the occasional vampiric weapon) and there's no garauntee you'll find anything that actually works well with your main combat stat. also poison is effectively incurable-if you can't survive until it passes on its own, you're dead.


While the game is flawed, it's still somewhat enjoyable if you stay away from the melee characters and the Battle for Stormrise quest. Playing as a Pixie Mage wearing plate armor and using a gun to shoot weapons out of your enemies hands is hard not to enjoy.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Unfortunate design and amazing imbalances make this one of the biggest game dissapointments I have yet to come across. You start with 3 characters out of 30, but they are so weak that you stand an impossible chance of any success.  The problem is that this might be the first and only game where you can only unlock characters by dieing. So get ready to farm hundreds and hundreds of deaths before you can actually have a chance of any fun. Oh, and be careful for the un-winnable scenarios. I loved spending an hour in a dungeon only to make a single wrong step and game over. If you get poisoned, it stays forever, ticking away health every step until you die.  The only way to cure it is to randomly find a magic dispel potion.  Please save yourself the frustration and avoid this at all costs.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is both brutally difficult, incredibly unfair, really annoying, and very tedious.

The game loves to set you up against masses of enemies that you are really not capable of dealing with (nor can you run away from).  Be prepared to miss with your attacks a lot, often in streaks of 10 or more in a row.  Also be ready to have very little health, and not many opportunities to refill it or increase it.  As you descend the enemies get harder and harder, and they get more cheap with their attack powers, such as poison that can take off half your health over time, fire attacks that can also destroy your equipment, and lighting attacks that can chain stun-lock you.

There is also no leveling system, you gain (and loose) attributes from equipment, which is further modified scrolls, potions, and altars.  The loot in general is also very boring and uninteresting, and you will often see the same equipment you didn't want over and over again.  The best part is that to unlock extra characters, the game expects you to die over and over again.  You start with 3 out of 32 characters unlocked.

I cannot recommend this game on any level.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a nice little turn based dungeon crawler.

About gameplay The maps and the loot and monsters therein are always randomly generated, which at the beginning can be quite frustrating as you have a steep learning curve as to how this game exactly works." Since you start out with rather weak characters (you unlock new ones by dying in/failing a quest) the game seems rather frustrating. But don't let that ruin your experience as you advance you'll unlock new characters and get to the fun/challenge of the game rather quickly and more easily.

The game completely bypasses difficult and complex skill and stat systems for a rather basic approach. You have 2 stats per weapon class (Attack Chance/Attack Damage) a defense skill and health. In addition to the stats there's an "elemental system." You can either cause
date: resist or have a vulnerability to one of the 7 damage types; silvered
voteText: poison
helpfulPercent: divine
votesHelpful:
necrotic and psychic. And that's it.

If you start the game up you'll first decide with which kind of character you want to play (32 in total once all are unlocked. You unlock new ones every N^2 deaths) you'll then decide what quest you want to approach (there are currently 6) and what artifacts to take with you (once you found any).

Depending on these choices you also set the difficulty for your game. Melee characters are hard to play with (since they need to get close first)

Depending on their starting elements or enchantements they also add or substract from the difficulty

with a starting character or artifact that makes you vulnerable towards fire damage.

Artifacts are found in specific encounters throughout the game or by finishing certain quests. Artifacts stay with you and can be selected as starting gear making your life significantly easier.

With all this in mind the games actual gameplay is rather simple but shines in one particular aspect: choice. In every quest there are 5 levels with certain enemies of certain quantities but they are nonetheless of the same kind. With this in mind the biggest challenge of the game is to take or not to take risks. As the "Loot" aspect in the title of the game suggests it makes you think rather hard on what to use and what not to use; "Are you taking this shield with you that makes you less likely to hit enemies and makes you vulnerable to psychic damage but gives you a steady defense stat that'll continually help you out whenever you are hit and in addition makes you resistant to poison?" or "Do I drink this potion which name doesn't suggest neither positive nor negative effects that could heal my low health but also make me vulnerable towards the current enemies most common element and therefor kill me?" are examples of the most common and frequent choices in the game.

A lot of other people think this game is "unfair" to them but it really isn't. It is true that a lot of luck and chance is involved in the game

Sound and Graphics Some words about sound and graphics: The graphics usually don't exceed the 10x10 Pixel boundary per sprite or background element so don't expect too much even though it features fantastic and distinctive design within this limitation and the sound is really nice. This is actually the only thing that bugs me: The music doesn't consecutively play throughout the game but rather plays one soundloop on occasion. Starting a quest? Soundtrack 1 loops once. Found a big amount of enemies? Soundtrack for danger loops once. And so on. reviewText:
*shakes head sadly*  Such a pity.

Look, I like roguelikes.  I really do.  I've played a good few, and I enjoy a desperate struggle with limited resources, where every choice matters and one bad move can ruin an entire run.  I like to have to make hard decisions and cheat death through careful planning, frantic improvisation and the rare lucky break.

Hack Slash Loot is the antithesis of those things.

Unless the game has undergone a  total makeover in terms of design since I last played it, it's a broken, pointless roguelike in which you stand absolutely no chance in hell of surviving (unless you get lucky and get a Holy/Virtue element weapon that boosts your stats with each hit, right at the start of your run).

The most potent strategy you have is Stand in front of a doorway to fight the enemies one on one
date:
and pray that the guys stuck behind the guy you're hitting don't loop around and flank you before you kill them all one at a time".  You can't even RUN.  The enemies chase you forever like homing missiles and will not stop until you've bopped them on the head enough to kill them.  There's no class-specific skills to use and manage either.  It's all about the items you find and pick up.  And getting them?  Random.  There are virtually no hard choices in the game.  Just roll the dice and pray you make it.

It's like playing russian roulette with a fully loaded gun.  There is no skill.  Only luck.  Winning (Or even PROGRESS) is impossible unless you get insanely lucky.

If you want a roguelike
recommended: go play FTL (a much better game)
voteText: if you want an action-based roguelike
helpfulPercent: Eldritch is pretty good and actually takes skills and quick thinking to beat.  Go play those or the many other good roguelikes out there.  Avoid hack slash loot at all costs."

reviewText:
Since I puchased this game, I've occaisonally come back to it to satisfy my dungeon itch while talking to people in the room, or waiting for something else. It (Hack,Slash,Loot) serves my purpose for it. For me, it is the simple, casual, non-engaging go-to game that I can walk away from at a moment's notice.

There's no saving the game. There's no rhyme or reason to the drops. The monster difficulty depends on the floor you're on. For cleared areas, the minimap navigation is a big time-saver. You could spend an hour building your character just to watch it get torn down in moments upon opening a door to a boss that is way stronger than expected.

Pro's:
- Casual. You can step right into it with zero load time and quick menus....and walk away from it just as fast
- Pixel graphics are simplistic and nostalgic
- Simple, fast learning curve. The gameplay reminds me of Temple of Apshai" of Apple II fame. Item upgrades and potions are easy to choose (or to know the effects that result)

Con's:
- No story
date:
beyond some paltry title page blurb. No sense of story progression either.
- Character ability is a set of stats that calculate based on to-hit and parry roles.
- No room for combat strategy. Just try to channelize groups of baddies and hope you outlast them.

In conclusion
recommended: if you wanted a rogue-like dungeon game that's story-rich and full of stimulating and complex battle strategy

reviewText: Hack Slash Loot is an 8 bit styled keyboard based rpg that makes Dungeon's of Dreadmore's graphics look high resolution by comparison.  The graphics themselves can be forgiven for their simplicity given the intentional style, and the music, although repetive, is not annoying.  My biggest complaint with Hack Slash Loot is the difficulty right out of the gate.  Within the first few minutes of gameplay I was being routinely killed by the first few creatures of each dungeon, resulting in a restart.  The lack of progression makes it hard to fully evaluate the game, but I definitely found it a turn off from the get go.  Grab Hack Slash loot only if you absolutely must as part of a pack or Humble Bundle, but otherwise it's not a title I can recommend.

reviewText:
Hack Slash Loot è un RPG puro, difficile ed estremamente longevo.

Pensato per essere realmente guidato dal fato e in minima parte dall'abilità delle proprie doti di giocatori, si può fare ben poco quando si beve la pozione sbagliata che disincanta tutti i propri oggetti magici, tuttavia ci si può trasformare in una macchina da guerra se le cose girano dalla nostra parte.

Nonostante l'apparente randomicità, il gameplay è del classico RPG per eccellenza, a turni e senza dare vantaggi a nessuno, ne a noi ne ai nemici.

Il gioco parte con personaggi deboli che moriranno senza scampo su tutti i livelli disponibili, poi man mano che moriremo, si sbloccheranno personaggi decisamente più interessanti come l'amazzone, probabilmente il personaggio più facile e potente da usare di tutto il gioco.

Se vi piace il genere puro RPG questo è un must, deve anche interessarvi poco la grafica, o almeno essere abbastanza vecchi da godervi un gioco a 8-bit in tutto il suo disarmante e scarno splendore.

PROS
- Puro RPG
- Immediato e semplice
- È come mangiare le patatine fritte, quando parti non riesci a fermarti
- Nonostante la disarmante semplicità grafica riesce ad essere vario
- Lo stile visuale è coerente e molto consistente

CONS
- Morire contro il mostro di fine quest, dopo 2-3 ore di gioco capita, spesso
- Morire contro un nemico a caso dopo molto impegno capita, spesso
- Frustranti capovolgimenti durante la partita
- Ci stava poter guidare più personaggi nella stessa partita
- Si sente la mancanza di uno story mode più profondo

reviewText:
It's very, very random. And that randomness is very, very skewed against you. There's some enemies you can't kill without having an item that gives you haste equipped, and you can easily run a whole dungeon and never find one.

Or the way that there's no skills, just a basic default attack, so you're never really involved in the combat.

Or how enemies with elemental resistance explode into an AOE of whatever damage type they have a resistance to, so I hope you aren't playing a melee character.

And how it's pretty much impossible to regen health unless you're lucky, so that chip damage is gonna kill you.

It's like they heard that Roguelikes make dying fun!" and decided to focus entirely on the dying part and ignore the whole "fun" thing."

reviewText: I have a soft spot for ole text games like Mysteria, which makes me really like Hack, Slash, Loot. The overall setting of the game can be changed with the quest in the beginning of the game, although you have the option of choosing your class and quest on the title screen you also have the awesome option of setting it all to random making your next quest and class a surprise. The mechanics of the game are somewhat light although the big picture of the game is to stay alive and make smart choices when it comes to battling monsters and maintaining your health points. The armor weapons and items you find in game offer tons of support and help you best the set of quests before you, but some items can also have cons associated with them. The random outcomes of the doors you choose can have a heavy impact on whether or not you die or make it to the next floor. I noticed that the ranged classes usually survive longer due to being able to bottleneck enemies in doorways and blast them from the safety of a long hallway. Overall Hack, Slash, Loot is an update of an older vision of games long lost in a crowd of easy shooters and games that play themselves.

reviewText:
I'm very fond of HSL, so I wish I could recommend this game more highly. Its appealingly nostalgic looking, fairly accessible, and charmingly simple - cutting back on a lot of roguelike conventions without losing the main idea. Looting and getting stronger is predictably addictive.

Unfortunately it still feels unpolished and balanced poorly, and the worst offender is the fact that there are just relatively few meaningful actions for the player to consider and take throughout a playthrough. Questions a player faces are two: whether or not to engage, or whether or not to equip - and the answers to those questions are often strikingly obvious. I also haven't found a single practical reason yet to focus on melee over ranged weaponry. That fact combined with a relatively common boost makes the experience very simple to game.

In some was HSL feels like an iOS casual game, with a veneer of hardcore trappings, minus the in-app purchases. But I am fond of it, and will keep playing a bit.

reviewText: This game's title is the perfect example of 'Truth In Advertising', and 'Exactly What It Says On The Tin'. With extremely retro graphics, and an almost overly simplistic style, the game is definitely not for everyone. However, as a mindless 'smash n' grab old-style RPG', this game is worth it. Small, compact, and with a surprising number of challenges in the gameplay above and beyond a simple 'kill, level, loot', I find this game to be an excellent 'time-waster' for a little something to play around with. If you want state-of-the-art gaming feel, give it a pass. But if you're a fan of 80s retro-style RPGs, give it a shot! At less than $10, you can't go wrong.

reviewText:
Time Played: 23 Hours
100% Achievements

Hack Slash Loot is an interesting attempt on the roguelike genre but has several flaws which make it great. Roguelikes have been traditionally difficult and reward intelligent player decisions, which gives players that sense of accomplishment after progression. But here, skill is pretty much a nonfactor with the only elements present being Don't get surrounded" or "Use elements enemies are weak to".

RNG will completely screw you over. It is entirely possible to die to the very first enemy you encounter. Hit chances are also extremely low in the beginning. Expect Miss-Miss-Hit-Miss-Hit every time you fight.

Another needlessly frustrating problem for the player is that there is no way to gain health other than by drinking random potions and hoping for the best (or gaining the op skill of regeneration).

Overall
date: a decent game but with all these problems
recommended:
it belongs in a mixed rating rather than yes/no.

Pros
Gets better after unlocking a few classes

Cons
Frustrating to progress
Die to RNG"

reviewText: Hack Slash Loot is an 8 bit styled keyboard based rpg that makes Dungeon's of Dreadmore's graphics look high resolution by comparison.  The graphics themselves can be forgiven for their simplicity given the intentional style, and the music, although repetive, is not annoying.  My biggest complaint with Hack Slash Loot is the difficulty right out of the gate.  Within the first few minutes of gameplay I was being routinely killed by the first few creatures of each dungeon, resulting in a restart.  The lack of progression makes it hard to fully evaluate the game, but I definitely found it a turn off from the get go.  Grab Hack Slash loot only if you absolutely must as part of a pack or Humble Bundle, but otherwise it's not a title I can recommend.

reviewText:
Since I puchased this game, I've occaisonally come back to it to satisfy my dungeon itch while talking to people in the room, or waiting for something else. It (Hack,Slash,Loot) serves my purpose for it. For me, it is the simple, casual, non-engaging go-to game that I can walk away from at a moment's notice.

There's no saving the game. There's no rhyme or reason to the drops. The monster difficulty depends on the floor you're on. For cleared areas, the minimap navigation is a big time-saver. You could spend an hour building your character just to watch it get torn down in moments upon opening a door to a boss that is way stronger than expected.

Pro's:
- Casual. You can step right into it with zero load time and quick menus....and walk away from it just as fast
- Pixel graphics are simplistic and nostalgic
- Simple, fast learning curve. The gameplay reminds me of Temple of Apshai" of Apple II fame. Item upgrades and potions are easy to choose (or to know the effects that result)

Con's:
- No story
date:
beyond some paltry title page blurb. No sense of story progression either.
- Character ability is a set of stats that calculate based on to-hit and parry roles.
- No room for combat strategy. Just try to channelize groups of baddies and hope you outlast them.

In conclusion
recommended: if you wanted a rogue-like dungeon game that's story-rich and full of stimulating and complex battle strategy

reviewText:
This feels like the most watered-down rogue-like experience ever. There's definitely a very good randomly-generated element to it, with randomly generated maps, enemy placements, loot, etc. What kills it for me, however, is the fact that there is barely anything to do in terms of combat -- there are three damage types (magic, melee, ranged), but the magic and ranged attacks play out identically in that they both have ranged attacks compared to melee's 1-tile range. In essence, it feels like the only reason there are ranged and magic damage types is so that the randomly generated loot isn't a coin flip to see if it's relevant to you or not.

I haven't seen anything resembling skills or abilities (though there are evidently artifacts that you can unlock once you beat a small campaign, allowing for better starting stats), so combat is literally just rolling the dice to see who hits and who doesn't with no room for any other options. As a result, playing with line of sight to minimize the amount of ranged attacks that can hit you during combat is the closest thing to tactics you'd have to employ. Inevitably, at many points in the game, you'll just spend many turns clicking on the same tile down a bottleneck, which is about as degenerate of an experience as I can imagine. Given how wild the RNG can be with the combat, sometimes even this much planning is not enough to do well, as enemies can hit devastatingly hard and your character's ~60% to hit does not perform as consistently as it would have you believe.

If you want a fantasy dice-rolling simulator, look no further. If you wanted something interactive or exciting, there are many better options out there.

reviewText:
An interesting 8-bit Roguelike game. Your only way to power up in this game is to find random loot and better upgrades as you explore these random-generating dungeons. The monsters can be tough even at the very beginning, but with some practice and hours of playing you will have better ways on avoiding them or having lesser numbers for every encounter. Get it while it's cheap if you're into Roguelike games or just looking for a cheap RPG to play while you are downloading bigger games.

PROS: Smallest download size, random-generated dungeons and loots to give hours of fun. Each character has their own traits and aren't too generic.

CONS: Enemies are tough even on the first level and can come in groups. While every character isn't too generic I happen to find the close-ranged fighters moderately hard to play due to many enemies fight in long distance and having to approach them can cost many hit points to my character.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a small roguelike game where you delve through dungeons while collecting all kinds of loot and killing monsters. It's fairly basic and a neat little time waster, don't expect anything groundbreaking. You have various classes and weapons at your disposal. Quests are randomized and can also be unlocked.

The mechanics are fairly straight forward but the combat can be a bit iffy, the rng in this game and luck factor can really frustrate at times because at times you will be missing a lot and if you play as a fragile class like the mage, this can end in quite some frustration.

The only thing I dislike are the graphics, not because they're ugly. They serve their purpose but it can be fiddly to play with such small sprites on the map and sometimes it's difficult to navigate through narrow corridors or target enemies.

reviewText:
Time Played: 23 Hours
100% Achievements

Hack Slash Loot is an interesting attempt on the roguelike genre but has several flaws which make it great. Roguelikes have been traditionally difficult and reward intelligent player decisions, which gives players that sense of accomplishment after progression. But here, skill is pretty much a nonfactor with the only elements present being Don't get surrounded" or "Use elements enemies are weak to".

RNG will completely screw you over. It is entirely possible to die to the very first enemy you encounter. Hit chances are also extremely low in the beginning. Expect Miss-Miss-Hit-Miss-Hit every time you fight.

Another needlessly frustrating problem for the player is that there is no way to gain health other than by drinking random potions and hoping for the best (or gaining the op skill of regeneration).

Overall
date: a decent game but with all these problems
recommended:
it belongs in a mixed rating rather than yes/no.

Pros
Gets better after unlocking a few classes

Cons
Frustrating to progress
Die to RNG"

reviewText:
I have put an embarassing amount of time into this little rogue-like-lite gem.

First the bad:

The graphics are embarassingly bad, with teeny sprites that have no animations.

For some reason, the console, which tells you crucial information about things happening around you, is obscured behind the map itself.

One or two glitches occur when continuing an earlier game, including torches blinking between torch and blood spot sprites.

The sound fits into the style of the game well, but it all sounds like someone cranked it out on sfxr in about 30 minutes or so.

Now the good:

The gameplay is both extremely simple and very deep.

The game has a ton of classes and artifacts to unlock, which will keep you coming back for more.

The gameplay is both fun and addicting.

This game is pretty difficult when you start out, and requires practice to improve at it.

You can pick this game up, play it for 30 minutes, and lay it back down without getting lost.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot: Not, Very, Good

There have been multiple occasions wherein I have tried to play Hack, Slash, Loot. Both times didn’t last very long… As you can tell by my total play time of an hour. I’m just gonna be straight and say I don’t like this game. But the fact that I’m reviewing it after an hour should be more than enough evidence of that.

The main issues I have with Hack, Slash, Loot stem from the fact that it is based entirely around luck, it’s rather shallow, and frankly it’s just unengaging. Also I wanted to play it more, but it’s now continuously crashing; thus preventing me from even giving the game another chance. It’s almost as if the game knows I’m not fond of it and it’s hiding from further examination!

Crashing aside Hack, Slash, Loot definitely has some cool ideas, but the game’s execution could definitely have used some work. When the game launches, after you’ve taken about five minutes to parse the UI, you can pick from a rather large selection of quests-- these are essentially the game’s ‘campaigns’; and four character classes. The game’s various quests are really just a set of parameters on the random dungeon generation. Apparently the dungeons span multiple floors and also contain bosses but I’ve never lived long enough to see one…

This is because the game pits you off against a nearly unending horde of monsters that do far too much damage, have way too much health, and almost comically out number you. Plus healing items are few and far between due to the random nature of the game’s loot. In the hour I’ve played I’ve probably run through thirty or forty dungeons.

Let that sink in.

My longest run was probably 20 minutes, and I still never made it past the first floor. Hell, I’ve died in the room that I spawned in.

Fighting hordes of powerful enemies can definitely be fun, other games prove this. But Hack, Slash, Loot’s reliance on luck permeates into the combat as well. Even with a 60% chance to hit I find myself missing the majority of my shots. A fight with a single monster can take upwards of ten turns or more, which are spent watching your character and the monster haplessly flail at one another only occasionally connecting. Once you finally land a hit and damage to the monster you have to hope that you roll well... or you’ll find yourself dealing almost no damage, making the fight take even longer.

There’s nothing like missing ten attacks only to land one and deal 2 damage.

The best way I can describe this game is that it feels like a Pen and Paper RPG, like Pathfinder… But without any of the systems that actually allow you to do the cool stuff.

There are no modifiers that help your dice rolls, or give you an edge. It’s just raw randomness.

Most of the time you simply rely on luck, and hope that the five orcs breathing down your neck miss more than you do. Or that you get a good weapon that can deal decent damage. But that only happened to me once, and then I promptly died.

This game definitely has potential. And it’s clearly there under the layers of randomness… But  as it stands Hack, Slash, Loot isn’t worth your time.

reviewText: Can't really recommend this. I like some roguelikes, but this one is too barebones for me. There's no skills or spells, no character building, no inventory (though you do get to use a weapon, helm, armor, etc). After playing 10-15 minutes I assumed I was missing something and there must be more to the game, so I visited the forums, but as near as I can tell that's really all there is to it. If you want a good roguelike, try Tales of Maj'Eyal or Dungeons of Dredmor instead, both have way more to offer than this.

reviewText:
This game is a complete gamble in terms of progression. And more often than not, you'll be struck by enemies with abysmal hit chances to suffer a fourth of your health in damage. Combat is mostly fruitless since your character doesn't level up and at best your enemy MIGHT drop their weapon or gear, which might be an improvement over what you currently have. Not only that, but enemies won't approach you ever to get into melee range unless you're out of sight. There is only one skill to master in this game: not getting surrounded. Except that enemies can and will go around to multiple doors and open them to surround you, or even spawn in areas you already cleared. I've played a fair few roguelikes in my time and this is one of the most luck based ones I've ever played.

Pros: Aesthetics have a nice pixel, retro look, simple interface, enemies actually use simple tactics
Cons: Completely luck based gameplay, enemies spawn in areas you've already cleared to backstab you, combat is nearly pointless because of infrequent item drops and no leveling system.

Closing word: Only get if you're a glutton for punishment and don't mind dying hundreds of times before you complete even one quest.

reviewText:
Another instantly addicting game, Hack, Slash, Loot by developer David Williamson is a work of turn based martial art. Roguelike, you have to take every chance, try every door and kill every creature in your path. Incredibly fun to play, you don’t know who or what is in the next room, leaving you on the edge of your seat making Hack, Slash, Loot a go to game.

First starting the game you are given the option of a Human, Wizard or Archer, with continued gameplay you are able to unlock another 29 over time. Throughout the game you will encounter hordes of monsters, demons, zombies, and a manifold of other creatures to battle. Being turn based, you have to wait your turn, so be prepared to click frantically until your turn comes only to miss and do it again. With that being said its not all clicking, there is a deeper level of gameplay involved in Hack, Slash, Loot. This game involves a tactical insight and understanding beyond pointing and clicking. Each different quests embodies another set of skills and approach at the game. The possibilities are endless, mixing and matching of accessories and armor make every run different and add a new level of excitement and draw to the game.

There are dark places in the world inhabited by evil denizens. Places filled with danger and foreboding where no ordinary man would dare to journey. However, there are a few who are willing to risk death in the name of good, in the name of justice, in the name of… valuable loot! Depending on what quest you choose you are given a backstory to give you a sense of what your goal is in your adventure. Within each of the different quests you encounter various creatures and characters that have roles in the story, or provide dialog pertaining to whats at hand. While some quests are easier than others, each are sure to keep you on your toes.

Play for a few minutes or get more serious and sit down for a few hours, the more you play Hack, Slash, Loot the deeper you become involved. The retro appeal of this game really sells it the most, imagine Realm of the Mad God meets MS-DOS Dungeons and Dragons, imagine Final Fantasy Tactics meets Hammerwatch, imagine playing while watching the animated Lord Of The Rings, because thats what I did and now I love this game. You have a control panel in front of you while navigating your hero throughout each quest. To the left you have the status of your character displaying armor and stats. In the middle, a mini map that lights up as you explore each room, this also serves as a quick point and click to get you across the level faster. On the right, the description and status of each tile, chest, monster or whatever you hover the mouse over.

With only the life you are given to start you must find chests or overturn dead bodies in order to find scrolls or potions to boost your health as well as other stats at the same time. These scrolls and potions are critical to gameplay and make Hack, Slash, Loot almost impossible to play without them. With 32 different classes to choose from, 6 unique quests, and an endless mixture of armor, weaponry and gear makes Hack, Slash, Loot an instant classic and a must have for any indie gamer.

Graphics: 6/10
Playability: 7/10
Story: 9/10
Challenge: 8/10
Replay Value: 7/10

reviewText: A true roguelike to the core.  No saves, no forgiveness.  Simple enough to pickup with needing to crawl through a wiki or even look at the button binds but complex enough that it'll leave you wanting to crawl through the halls looking for spells, equipment, and glyphs to prepare you for the next level.\n\nThe game allows you to truly randomize your experience by choosing both your hero and your quest scenario (though you can specify both if you wish).  From there, it generates randomized levels that you crawl through and encounter specific bosses to progress your quest.  Should you be lucky enough to complete the quest, you'll unlock an achievement and start all over with another quest.  The game is made specifically difficult to exemplify the roguelike experience.  If you hate the feeling of losing everything and having to start over, this game is not for you.

reviewText:
An extremely minimalist Rogue-like which initially may seem like it involves little more than dice rolling and therefore unavoidable death.  However, once you unlock a few characters and start to learn how to manipulate the odds in your favour, the game really begins to open up.

The other nice touch is that all the achievements are possible to get just by playing the game normally and you can easily set up the odd one or two that you missed along the way.

My only complaint is that you start the game with three relatively dull vanilla characters which might put off new players that  may otherwise be unaware of fun unlockables such as the Ninja, Pirate or Scout.

To sum up, it's certainly not a game for everyone but it can be a very rewarding experience especially when you finally beat that first map!

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a Roguelike RPG, meaning that you start with a new character every time and play until you die or win, gaining little except for skill between playthroughs.

HSL has a high learning curve, which is a problem since the game tells you nothing about how to play. The interface does nothing to help. It took me about ten deaths to figure out how to do well enough to live for more than a few minutes. It takes a lot of time and research to play HSL effectively, but once you know some of the basics, the game becomes more fun.

What HSL does right is removing the player's inventory. You only carry what you have equipped. Everything else is dropped or used. This simplifies the mechanics a lot and streamlines play. The downside is that I found the mechanics to be a little shallow for a Roguelike, and much of your success depends on luck. The game is very poorly balanced.

HSL isn't the best Roguelike, but there's fun to be found. It's worth getting if you find it on sale.

reviewText:
An extremely minimalist Rogue-like which initially may seem like it involves little more than dice rolling and therefore unavoidable death.  However, once you unlock a few characters and start to learn how to manipulate the odds in your favour, the game really begins to open up.

The other nice touch is that all the achievements are possible to get just by playing the game normally and you can easily set up the odd one or two that you missed along the way.

My only complaint is that you start the game with three relatively dull vanilla characters which might put off new players that  may otherwise be unaware of fun unlockables such as the Ninja, Pirate or Scout.

To sum up, it's certainly not a game for everyone but it can be a very rewarding experience especially when you finally beat that first map!

reviewText: Hack, Slash, Loot is one of the most fun rogue-likes I have played. It's got a great randomness to it, lots of loot, and some really clever elements like quests/themes to the runs. The quests (run themes) element of the game makes this feel very objective oriented with goals that you can work towards (completing a quest for example). While there are definitely issues such as AI causing problems, and not clearest item stats system, neither has a dramatic effect on the overall enjoyment of the game.\n\nIf you're a rogue-like fan, and you enjoy pixel/retro style graphics I highly recommend this game. However, it is hard, it does take a while to master and it will be frustrating just like a rogue-like should.

reviewText: Okay, so.  This game is sadistic, as most roguelikes are, but not too complicated. reviewText:
Extremely hard. No way of healing during combat, death is permanant, no inventory (which sounds dumb I know) so the only way of carrying your loot is in your equip slots. You will die heaps but deaths unlock new classes. Randomly generated dungeons make it almost impossible to progress sometimes but rarely, be warned though, if you choose a hard quest to start off with, it could be generated to be even harder than it was initially.

If you like 'Roguelike' genre games, think Dungeons of Dredmor, Pokémon MD, The Tower of Druaga etc., give this game a go. Highly recommended.

Protips:
- Start off with the Wizard class. He's ranged and magic damage negates armor.
- 'Mask of the boy king' is by far the easiest quest to attempt.
- Try to resist opening tombs or crypts unless you're farmed up with gear as 90% of the time they spawn skeletons and demons. The loot from chests will sustain you with pots and gear. Monsters from tombs/crypts do however, always drop gear.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot. The title describes everything you do in the game.

It has been described as a roguelike, it looks like a roguelike, but it completly misses the mark in terms of gameplay. There is no resource management, there seems to be no risk in using potions and scrolls; they all buff. Every entity seems to move at the same speed, which is not inherently bad, but limits the tactical landscape. There is very little thought involved while playing this.

In terms of playability, perspective can get the better of you if you are not careful around enemies. Sometimes an enemy is visible, but can not be targeted with a ranged attack, which seems strange at times. Otherwise, the simple gameplay leads to simple controlls making it very accessable.

What was done well: the starting classes feel very different from each other in play. Allies intelligently stay out of your way in travel, but in combat situations they may block your path to the enemies and get themselves killed. Enemies stay out of reach generally, unless they have companions, which is interesting.

All in all, if you are looking for a casual turn-based dungeon crawler you may enjoy this. If you are looking for a thought-provoking roguelike then pass on this.

For Linux users
The game runs on Wine, so if it's something you're interested in, you have the option to play it.

reviewText: While certainly not a ground-breaking game, Hack, Slash, Loot is fun for what it is: an old school dungeon crawler that is unforgiving in difficulty.  Over time, a few updates have been added to spice it up with new characters, though it hasn't changed the gameplay or style (a plus for me as I appreciate what it has to offer).\nIf you're looking for something flashy or complex; look elsewhere.  If you're content with old-school dungeon crawling, 8-bit graphics, occassional insane spikes in difficulty when attacked by a multitude of monsters simultaneously, and an oddly comforting interface and simplicity, then Hack, Slash, Loot is for you.

reviewText: If RNG rogue-likes are your thing, look no further than Hack, Slash, Loot. Level layout and enemy generation both perfectly balance the procedural generation of a rogue-like with the intentionality of a well-designed level. Unfortunately, other randomized elements are less-than-perfect. With a peculiarly inverted difficulty curve, players will find the greatest initial challenge is persevering through the 25+ deaths required to unlock the first character truly capable of rewarding a player's skill with success. Each successive character is more powerful than the last, and although some strategy is necessary in combining character classes with various artifact 'loadouts,' most of the later unlocked characters make previous ones obsolete. Similarly, choosing wisely from the loot at the player's disposal requires careful consideration, but the randomness of enchantments and loot mean that a session typically ends in either frustrating defeat or unsatisfying triumph.\n\nOn the spectrum of skill vs chance, Hack, Slash, Loot is just a bit more random than most players will find rewarding. Nevertheless, there is a wealth of unlockables that may keep a determined gamer occupied for many hours. For its unique interface and enjoyable retro stylings, the game is commendable, but overall it comes off as a quirky experiment that doesn't quite make the cut.

reviewText:
In all fairness, Hack, Slash, Loot (HSL) is a decent rogue-like. Realistically, how would any human fare trying to kill a dungeon full of ogres, undead skeletons or parasitic demons that burst out of his fallen comrades? The answer: he'd probably die long before reaching his goal.

HSL's main feature is arguably the starting character choice and the initial artifact they can bring with them (in case they have unlocked it). You start out with 3 mostly crap characters and then you unlock more through either a) successfully clearing a session or b) dying a certain number of times until the next unlock threshold. For most people, their first few unlocks may be the death based ones.

An interesting" design choice was the strengths/weaknesses of elements in the game. To sum it up
date: every element has a chance of doing some effect. If you're strong against the effect
recommended: you take half the damage and never suffer from the effect of that element; if you're weak
voteText: you take double damage and the chance of being applied the element's effect is increased. This comes with some very nasty consequences
helpfulPercent: such as being poisoned for a bad evasion roll or having a random piece of your equipment destroyed by fire. It gets even worse when you figure out that holy and dark elements' effect is applied when you kill something and that both give you health
votesHelpful: increased accuracy (aka hit enemies more often) or even increased damage: the game is practically forcing you to find and stick to a holy/dark weapon combo of melee
votesTotal: ranged or magic varieties
votesFunny: since randomly finding a potion and carelessly using it without knowing what its affix might do is bound to either screw all you've worked for or not heal you when you'd really want some health.\n\nHSL also starts handing you characters that are arguably better for specific dungeons or have gameplay variability to help you find your niche. One particular character has intrinsically magic resistance
commentsCount: for instance: you'd definitely want to bring him to at least two of the dungeons for that reason alone. But on the other hand

column17: and the arguable best stat to stock upon is armour (which
column18: unfortunately
column19: is more likely to come from your randomly dropped equipment than it is from being boosted from a potion) because it is applied BEFORE strengths and weaknesses come into play.\n\nAs for the artifacts
column20: the undeniably best all-around one is the Mask of SomeMummyGuy (name forgotten
column22: the goal from the crypt dungeon and forever unlocked once obtained. There is no real reason not to bring it with you either
column23: since it boasts an incredible amount of armour and reasonable stat boosts for your offensive ability. Compare to the Butcher's Knife
column24: which makes you walk twice a turn but does such an insignificant amount of damage that you'll be seeing the numbers 1 or 2 popping out when you attack something
column26: which if you aren't a melee character or don't have holy or dark weapons means you will also be hitting a lot less for the "benefit" of being able to pass through walls (which may sound nice
column27: but on most of the dungeons it simply means that if you don't clear a room FAST the monsters are going to start opening doors EVERYWHERE and the entire level is going to make a never-ending conga line to beat you up).\n\nAlso keep in mind
column28: my worst gripe with HSL isn't about the gameplay but the accuracy of targetting itself
column29: a game mechanic. As you may see from the screenshots
column30: tiles are rectangular: they are wider than taller by a ratio of aproximately 2. And when you want to click on something

reviewText: Hack, Slash, Loot is exactly what you expect it to be. It's a cute little rogue-like with adorable graphics and a friendly User Interface. reviewText:
I see most people talking about how this game is too simple and too luck based. Well, for most of us who played Rogue-likes back in the 16-bit era, we took simple games and we learned how to roll with the punches. Guide large groups of enemies through doorways, keep two types of weapons, drink and use all potions/scrolls (except for dispel, trust me.), and take what's given to you and use it to the best of your ability.

And if the game is still too hard, do the Boy with the Mask first. Easiest of all the quests and you can get two artifacts that can really help you.

One of my complaints, however, is that even after being out for two years, there has been no released content for the game. So once you unlock everything, all you have to look forward too is repeating the same quests. I am content with that, but I know a lot of people who wouldn't.

So it's a hit and miss kind of game. If you like challenging, barebone games, then pick it up. If you like games with expansive spells and weapons, this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
HSL is a roguelike, which has had all the complexity (and fun taken out of it). It's almost as if the author has read the wikipedia entry on a roguelike and then decided to write one without ever trying trying to play one.

There are no tactics (other than move backwards and fire), no specific skills to learn required. You are at the mercy of the random number generator - a random number generator that seems very tempermental.

If you like roguelikes, save your money and play a decent one instead.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot reminds me a lot of how the old ASCII Nethack plays. It is at its core exceptionally brutal, however surprisingly enjoyable. Much of the games drops are out of your control and left to the dice (random number generator) which can either be in your favor or not. You must use doors and hallways to your advantage to limit monsters' ability to get swings on you which will greatly increase the odds in your favor. It is as close to a classic in terms of atmosphere and feel as you can get. It will not hold your hand, It will not give you tips or hints, It will do its best to kill you.

I've nearly clocked twenty hours and I have thus far died fifty five times with only four victories.

Highly recommended if you don't mind a challenge

reviewText:
Not at any price.

Hack, Slash, Loot is hard to even describe. It is a game that essentially boils down what it means to be a game to its simplest level. Step one: Left click. Step two: Left click. Are you dead? Restart. Go to step one.

While the game boasts multiple classes and multiple quests, there are almost zero differences to be found regardless of your choice. There are no activatable abilities, of any nature. Combat is all dice rolling against your accuracy, which can begin at a pitiful 60% base chance to hit. Monster variety consists of melee or ranged, and what element they might hit you with or be weak to. Everything else boils down to dealing out and taking increasingly larger numbers of damage.

Your only stats are accuracy, damage, health, and defense. In almost all cases, every item or consumable will simply futz with those numbers a bit. Or, give you weakness/resistance to an element, which is of limited utility. A very rare find will give you two actions per turn. This is about the only time actual tactics are involved, as otherwise everything moves just as fast as you do.

Making matters worse, friendly NPCs can make certain quests nearly unplayably obnoxious for their ability to get in your way, die, and spawn a ghost who will turn on you.

Essentially, Hack Slash Loot brought in the worst parts of classic Rogue games, but somewhere along the way forgot to add in the things that make them fun.

Here's a video with a look at the gameplay:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=raXofWn2ayY

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game. This game does not feel like a completed product.

Audio
This game lacks music. Most of your gameplay is filled with digital squeeks and sfx of the character's actions. The sounds get monotonous and boring.

Gameplay
This game is not repetitive for a dungeon crawler. This is good. The game was enjoyable for the first few hours. However, you'll realize that the randomly generated maps are at times impossible to complete. For example, you start a new game, and you spawn right next to a hobgoblin. You'll die. You won't be able to kill it, not with getting artifacts. The chances of getting artifacts are very low, considering that you'll have much more difficulty in trying to survive the first level, let alone trying to find artifacts.

You might be complaining that these vanilla" gamers don't know what difficult is. Well

reviewText: Hack Slash Loot is great fun. A rougelike-like, dungeon crawling RPG game, with a cutie pixel-art graphics style, and challenging gameplay. It's a turn based game, where each time you move on a tile, you along with everything else in the dungeon takes a turn, and you go through the dungeon completing quests. At the main menu you'll pick a character/class, each which have their own stats and unique style of play (melee, magic, ranged, etc) and depending on the quest, some may be better than others. You also choose the quest you want to play from the main menu, and each has its own story. But everytime you play one of these quests, the dungeon is different, since they're procedurally generated. (Though depending on the quest, they'll follow a certain blueprint". For instance
date: a quest that takes place in a large tower will always have a circular shaped map/dungeon). Fun
voteText: HSL is a great way to spend a half an hour or so."

reviewText:
Not at any price.

Hack, Slash, Loot is hard to even describe. It is a game that essentially boils down what it means to be a game to its simplest level. Step one: Left click. Step two: Left click. Are you dead? Restart. Go to step one.

While the game boasts multiple classes and multiple quests, there are almost zero differences to be found regardless of your choice. There are no activatable abilities, of any nature. Combat is all dice rolling against your accuracy, which can begin at a pitiful 60% base chance to hit. Monster variety consists of melee or ranged, and what element they might hit you with or be weak to. Everything else boils down to dealing out and taking increasingly larger numbers of damage.

Your only stats are accuracy, damage, health, and defense. In almost all cases, every item or consumable will simply futz with those numbers a bit. Or, give you weakness/resistance to an element, which is of limited utility. A very rare find will give you two actions per turn. This is about the only time actual tactics are involved, as otherwise everything moves just as fast as you do.

Making matters worse, friendly NPCs can make certain quests nearly unplayably obnoxious for their ability to get in your way, die, and spawn a ghost who will turn on you.

Essentially, Hack Slash Loot brought in the worst parts of classic Rogue games, but somewhere along the way forgot to add in the things that make them fun.

reviewText: You won't have the same experience twice, hopefully you won't have to endure it once.  This game consists of random dungeons full of NPCs that will take roughly one eternity to resolve nothing.  I spent a good 20 turns of combat where both I and my opponent missed eachother time after time.  I wish I could say this was an isolated incident, but it happens each playthrough.\nThe random dungeons often start you in a room with two or more enemies who will annihilate you before your adventure begins.\nObviously I didn't get this game for its looks, but nothing else feels good about it.  Don't waste what precious time you have.

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game. This game does not feel like a completed product.

Audio
This game lacks music. Most of your gameplay is filled with digital squeeks and sfx of the character's actions. The sounds get monotonous and boring.

Gameplay
This game is not repetitive for a dungeon crawler. This is good. The game was enjoyable for the first few hours. However, you'll realize that the randomly generated maps are at times impossible to complete. For example, you start a new game, and you spawn right next to a hobgoblin. You'll die. You won't be able to kill it, not with getting artifacts. The chances of getting artifacts are very low, considering that you'll have much more difficulty in trying to survive the first level, let alone trying to find artifacts.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a game that I got as part of a bundle, that I dearly wish had never been redeemed. Its presence, forever a taint on my library.

Avoid this game, for this game is precision crafted to avoid literally everything good about roguelikes ever. Hack, Slash, Loot is such a bad roguelike that it can be considered the anti-roguelike, the embodiment of all the bad parts of roguelikes with none of the good whatsoever.

The game lacks any sort of mechanical depth whatsoever. Everything boils down to boring, static numbers. Where a better roguelike would have classes that play differently, different skills perhaps, equipment preferences and the like, the ability to use magic perhaps, this game has none of those things. And I'm not saying that a roguelike has to have those things, you understand. I'm saying that most fantasy roguelikes would have those things, for instance Dungeons of Dredmor and Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup. Even within the Roguelite" games
date: you'd have characters with a vastly different playstyle resulting from different skillsets
hoursPlayed: like in The Binding of Isaac
voteText: Risk of Rain
helpfulPercent: Nuclear Throne
votesTotal: the list goes on.\n\nHack
votesFunny: Slash
commentsCount: Loot instead has classes that boil down to melee and ranged
column16: no resting to regain your health
column17: no skills
column18: no mana. Your character is simply a walking sheet of stats
column19: bolstered by your equipment that are nothing but stats. This creates no interesting gameplay choices
column20: either you find something that has better stats than your current equipment
column21: or you don't. There is no strategy
column22: there is no way to build your character
column23: there is no game to be enjoyed here.\n\nThis creates a game that is nothing but dice rolls upon dice rolls
column24: with little to no player input involved. There is no feeling of accomplishment if you get further than you previously did
column25: there is no anguish when you die. You cannot self reflect on a defeat that was entirely out of your control
column26: you cannot ask yourself what you could've done better.\n\nThe beauty of a roguelike is its nigh infinite replayability
column27: the ways you can experiment with builds
column28: the magic of discovery as you find something that works
column29: figure out the tricks of the game
column30: and get further everytime. The excitement when you turn a bad run around after an item that perfectly synergizes with your current character appears
column33: even perhaps to the final level
column34: before dying. Lamenting that you would've won if you had the right items. And what about the times when you pull through a bad run? That is the core of the roguelike experience that Hack
column36: Loot ultimately fails to capture.\n\nIn conclusion
column39: Loot is a thoroughly incompetent roguelike that tries to distill the experience
column40: but what you instead get is a shallow game with no identity
column41: no soul. It is a bad game
column43: and you should avoid it like the plague."

reviewText:
I realize many people give this game ALOT of flak, and I can understand why. The game is very much random in how things play out, and people often hate that.

I find the complete randomness to be very enjoyable, and makes every turn a tense, though fun turn of events!

The game can be unforgiving, but a real dungeon experience would be difficult if one was in such a situation, right?

All the negative reviews on that pop up when you 1st look up this game will deter alot of people I think. That's not fair to me. Especially at the current $7.00 price tag, this game should not be passed up.


- The game is difficult, it can be rough and unforgiving, but you get a CHALLENGE nonetheless! Doing well on a run when you know the odds can be against you? That's a truely gratifying experience. You're not really breaking your wallet on this one.

Don't let all the negative comments push you away, consider this game! Cheers!

reviewText:
Is this game too random?

Brogue, Dragon Age, Risk of Rain, ToME, Realm of the Mad God, Binding of Isaac, Spelunky, Minecraft... I could sit here and try to name many more games, all of which use random elements. In some your attacks always hit as long as you aim it right. Usually though it is based on chance whether you hit somebody or not, and how much damage you do. To improve your chances you improve your stats. Nearly all games rely on random elements such as item drops, enemy spawning, and more. This one just puts it more up front and in your face than most others.

You didn't always get your way in Nethack, or any of the older roguelikes. The same can be said for any new RPG, roguelike, or a mix of both, such as Spelunky or Binding of Isaac. You had to keep going, and hope that you got lucky enough for good items, easy enemies, a good floor layout, etc. You strategized what to do from there, based on what the game decided to throw at you. The only thing I feel it really needs would probably have to be longer chapters/areas, the ability to continue going on after defeating a boss, or some sort of infinite dungeon.

In my opinion I think that, while it does need improvements, tweaks, and hopefully more content, this game offers a view to the more classic idea of roguelikes. I'm definitely keeping my eye on this one.

( I play this DRM free and not on steam, hence the low play time. )

reviewText:
Pros:
- It was just over a dollar on the Humble Bundle store
- Nice art style
- Some decent gameplay concepts, like friendly NPCs that will fight alongside you
- Simple, responsive mouse controls

Cons:
- No inventory, WTF?
- NO SAVE FEATURE?!?!?!?
- Interface isn't well defined, could use some minor tweaks
- Extremely limited character class selection
- Nearly impossible to find healing items
- No apparent experience/leveling system

Overall:
I want to like this game, as I like the concept, and I find the controls to be extremely fluid and intuitive, but there are just so many basic things that this game is missing. I would play the living crap out of this if they introduced a proper inventory and leveling system, as well as the ability to save your game. It's sad to see such wasted potential.
