reviewText:
I've spent quite a few hours playing this game off steam and only got it there for the cards. It's bad, really bad.

It's not just hard, it's unfair. There are so many misses you'll often be bored to tears looking at a whiff-fest. There are very few choices to make and even less that matter. Skill plays little role (and is utterly negligible compared to random luck) and I have found no depth whatsoever in this.

I haven't had a single minute or moment of fun in this game, ever. I don't know why someone would want to play it. I may have missed something, but if you have to search for more than 4 hours then there's a big problem with the game.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a small roguelike game where you delve through dungeons while collecting all kinds of loot and killing monsters. It's fairly basic and a neat little time waster, don't expect anything groundbreaking. You have various classes and weapons at your disposal. Quests are randomized and can also be unlocked.

The mechanics are fairly straight forward but the combat can be a bit iffy, the rng in this game and luck factor can really frustrate at times because at times you will be missing a lot and if you play as a fragile class like the mage, this can end in quite some frustration.

The only thing I dislike are the graphics, not because they're ugly. They serve their purpose but it can be fiddly to play with such small sprites on the map and sometimes it's difficult to navigate through narrow corridors or target enemies.

reviewText:
This Game is honestly a bit of a dissapointment (probably more so if you got it for full price, I got it from a humble bundle). It looks like it should be a nice game, and while it does have its charm, but just not enough to make up for its flaws.

PROS:
-A number of artifacts, once you find one, you can choose to start with that artifact in any future game.
-A nice weapon/armor material system, silver weapons disarm foes, gold weapons give you stat bonuses occasionally, psychic weapons causes stat drain, among other things
-A couple of nice references to other (better) games in the form of some artifacts and uncommon rooms (such as an Aperture test chamber and I'm pretty sure I saw the castle crashers knights once)
-Despite not having an inventory (kind of a good thing, to be honest-it leads to less of the hoarding mentality many RPGs end up with) it does have a secondary weapon slot, and you can switch between the two easily, which I thought was a nice little feature.

CONS:
-Melee is awful-seriously, there's almost no reason to use it.
-combat is dull and repetetive (there's literally nothing beyond 'attack' and 'move')
-more than one or two friendly NPCs completely bog down the pace of the game
-Unlocking more characters seems to be completely random
-Death is frequent, not because the game is hard, but because healing is almost exclusively availible from random potions/scrolls/food (and the occasional vampiric weapon) and there's no garauntee you'll find anything that actually works well with your main combat stat. also poison is effectively incurable-if you can't survive until it passes on its own, you're dead.


While the game is flawed, it's still somewhat enjoyable if you stay away from the melee characters and the Battle for Stormrise quest. Playing as a Pixie Mage wearing plate armor and using a gun to shoot weapons out of your enemies hands is hard not to enjoy.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Unfortunate design and amazing imbalances make this one of the biggest game dissapointments I have yet to come across. You start with 3 characters out of 30, but they are so weak that you stand an impossible chance of any success.  The problem is that this might be the first and only game where you can only unlock characters by dieing. So get ready to farm hundreds and hundreds of deaths before you can actually have a chance of any fun. Oh, and be careful for the un-winnable scenarios. I loved spending an hour in a dungeon only to make a single wrong step and game over. If you get poisoned, it stays forever, ticking away health every step until you die.  The only way to cure it is to randomly find a magic dispel potion.  Please save yourself the frustration and avoid this at all costs.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is both brutally difficult, incredibly unfair, really annoying, and very tedious.

The game loves to set you up against masses of enemies that you are really not capable of dealing with (nor can you run away from).  Be prepared to miss with your attacks a lot, often in streaks of 10 or more in a row.  Also be ready to have very little health, and not many opportunities to refill it or increase it.  As you descend the enemies get harder and harder, and they get more cheap with their attack powers, such as poison that can take off half your health over time, fire attacks that can also destroy your equipment, and lighting attacks that can chain stun-lock you.

There is also no leveling system, you gain (and loose) attributes from equipment, which is further modified scrolls, potions, and altars.  The loot in general is also very boring and uninteresting, and you will often see the same equipment you didn't want over and over again.  The best part is that to unlock extra characters, the game expects you to die over and over again.  You start with 3 out of 32 characters unlocked.

I cannot recommend this game on any level.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot is a nice little turn based dungeon crawler.

About gameplay The maps and the loot and monsters therein are always randomly generated, which at the beginning can be quite frustrating as you have a steep learning curve as to how this game exactly works." Since you start out with rather weak characters (you unlock new ones by dying in/failing a quest) the game seems rather frustrating. But don't let that ruin your experience as you advance you'll unlock new characters and get to the fun/challenge of the game rather quickly and more easily.

The game completely bypasses difficult and complex skill and stat systems for a rather basic approach. You have 2 stats per weapon class (Attack Chance/Attack Damage) a defense skill and health. In addition to the stats there's an "elemental system." You can either cause
date: resist or have a vulnerability to one of the 7 damage types; silvered
voteText: poison
helpfulPercent: divine
votesHelpful:
necrotic and psychic. And that's it.

If you start the game up you'll first decide with which kind of character you want to play (32 in total once all are unlocked. You unlock new ones every N^2 deaths) you'll then decide what quest you want to approach (there are currently 6) and what artifacts to take with you (once you found any).

Depending on these choices you also set the difficulty for your game. Melee characters are hard to play with (since they need to get close first)
votesTotal: ranged characters have a medium difficulty (since they can shoot from afar) and wizards are easier to play with (since their shots penetrate armor if the enemy hasn't got an enchantement against it). Depending on their starting elements or enchantements they also add or substract from the difficulty
votesFunny: based on which quest you are approaching. It'd
commentsCount: for example
column16: be quite foolish to try and attempt the "They Dwell beneath" Quest
column17: wherein you go out to hunt down 5 dragons in a mountain
column18:
with a starting character or artifact that makes you vulnerable towards fire damage.

Artifacts are found in specific encounters throughout the game or by finishing certain quests. Artifacts stay with you and can be selected as starting gear making your life significantly easier.

With all this in mind the games actual gameplay is rather simple but shines in one particular aspect: choice. In every quest there are 5 levels with certain enemies of certain quantities but they are nonetheless of the same kind. With this in mind the biggest challenge of the game is to take or not to take risks. As the "Loot" aspect in the title of the game suggests it makes you think rather hard on what to use and what not to use; "Are you taking this shield with you that makes you less likely to hit enemies and makes you vulnerable to psychic damage but gives you a steady defense stat that'll continually help you out whenever you are hit and in addition makes you resistant to poison?" or "Do I drink this potion which name doesn't suggest neither positive nor negative effects that could heal my low health but also make me vulnerable towards the current enemies most common element and therefor kill me?" are examples of the most common and frequent choices in the game.

A lot of other people think this game is "unfair" to them but it really isn't. It is true that a lot of luck and chance is involved in the game
column19: however this feeling of "unfairness" will usually go away once you've understood the game and beaten it once or twice. While it is based on chance and luck a lot you'll
column20: as it is always the case with luck and chance
column21: on >average< succeed quite steadily. That's what odds are all about. If you get into the game a bit statements will quickly go from:"Stupid game always spawns too many enemies and no good loot
column22:
to:Maybe I should've taken that other helm with me instead and risk being poisened so that I'd have received less normal damage by upping my defence."

Sound and Graphics Some words about sound and graphics: The graphics usually don't exceed the 10x10 Pixel boundary per sprite or background element so don't expect too much even though it features fantastic and distinctive design within this limitation and the sound is really nice. This is actually the only thing that bugs me: The music doesn't consecutively play throughout the game but rather plays one soundloop on occasion. Starting a quest? Soundtrack 1 loops once. Found a big amount of enemies? Soundtrack for danger loops once. And so on. I'd have wished for a soundtrack that stayed with me for the entirety of a playthrough whenever there is no occasion for a loop. However the effects are nice and will kind of feel like a soundtrack after a while.

Is this a game for me? So all in all: If you are NOT easily frustrated when confronted with chellange or a little bad luck
column23: you like roguelikes and turn based dungeon crawlers or simply crave for a little bit of "something else" then please give this game a try. It'll surely not disappoint.\n\nIf you are easily bored or frustrated when confronted with chellange or a little bad luck stay far away from this game."

reviewText: Poorly balanced, each run's difficulty is anywhere on a scale of normal" to "completely-broken-impossible
date:
with most beyond the impossible mark.  I hear it gets easier after you unlock more stuff so your starting stats are better, but I don't want to waste hours waiting for the run where I am fortunate enough to progress.

It's a shame, it could be fun. The combat movement and ranged mechanics are simple and offer a bit of skill, but does very little to offset the immense amount of luck involved. Even a simple change like increasing your starting health and changing nothing else would allow you to progress at least a bit further each run increasing the chance of finding some good treasure to get you started.

3/10

reviewText:
Firstly, this game is not as awful as people say. It's not unwinnable, I certainly managed to win it. I stopped playing the game because it became too easy for me, but that's because I have a lot of good gear (due to winning the game) and knowledge about the game after playing for 80 hours. I was very persistent and I learned more every time I died.

I must be one of the few people who really enjoyed this game. I greatly enjoyed the challenge and tried to get just a little further each time, before finally making it. Roguelike perma-death games that reward you for trying and trying are quite hilarious.

This game only lets you have a small amount of gear, but the gear is vital. The combination of gear lets you take less (or more) damage from certain types of damage, as well as improving your ability to hurt stuff.

There's a ton of luck involved, but a lot of skill. As I played more and more, I realised which classes worked well on which levels. I worked out when to fully explore certain areas with certain classes and when to rush to the next area.

Some people won't like this game because of the graphics, and that's certainly one downside. Others won't like this game because it's repetitive and because you only have the ability to only carry a small amount of loot.

I loved the game because of the challenge of the game, the complex simplicity of the gear management, and the huge amount of enjoyment I got when I started winning games.

reviewText:
Seeing the reviews that this small and fun game has, I've decided to add mine to counter the negativity.
I have to admit, I too would avoid buying unless you:
- like experimenting and trying odd indie games and their features
- like Binding of Isaac or any other hardcore-ish rogue-likes
- are able to multi-task (e.g. play the game and watch a film/listen to an audio-book/...)
- genuinely enjoy unlocking new hard-earned stuff
- have a lots of free time on your hands
So if you're a COD player, run for your life.
However, If you meet at least 2 of any of the points, get the game or wait for the nearest sale, I guarantee you'll enjoy it. I myself enjoyed every second (well, tbh, except couple of the first ones...) of the 34 hours that it took me to achieve every single achievement in the game and explore nearly every possibility and mechanic in it. I totally recommend! You'll thank me (and the dev) yet, when you manage to make it to the end of your first dungeon after dying again and again - that sense of accomplishment is definitely the best thing that a game can give you.

reviewText:
An interesting 8-bit Roguelike game. Your only way to power up in this game is to find random loot and better upgrades as you explore these random-generating dungeons. The monsters can be tough even at the very beginning, but with some practice and hours of playing you will have better ways on avoiding them or having lesser numbers for every encounter. Get it while it's cheap if you're into Roguelike games or just looking for a cheap RPG to play while you are downloading bigger games.

PROS: Smallest download size, random-generated dungeons and loots to give hours of fun. Each character has their own traits and aren't too generic.

CONS: Enemies are tough even on the first level and can come in groups. While every character isn't too generic I happen to find the close-ranged fighters moderately hard to play due to many enemies fight in long distance and having to approach them can cost many hit points to my character.

Overall Rating: 8 out of 10.

reviewText:
It's very, very random. And that randomness is very, very skewed against you. There's some enemies you can't kill without having an item that gives you haste equipped, and you can easily run a whole dungeon and never find one.

Or the way that there's no skills, just a basic default attack, so you're never really involved in the combat.

Or how enemies with elemental resistance explode into an AOE of whatever damage type they have a resistance to, so I hope you aren't playing a melee character.

And how it's pretty much impossible to regen health unless you're lucky, so that chip damage is gonna kill you.

It's like they heard that Roguelikes make dying fun!" and decided to focus entirely on the dying part and ignore the whole "fun" thing."

reviewText: I have a soft spot for ole text games like Mysteria, which makes me really like Hack, Slash, Loot. The overall setting of the game can be changed with the quest in the beginning of the game, although you have the option of choosing your class and quest on the title screen you also have the awesome option of setting it all to random making your next quest and class a surprise. The mechanics of the game are somewhat light although the big picture of the game is to stay alive and make smart choices when it comes to battling monsters and maintaining your health points. The armor weapons and items you find in game offer tons of support and help you best the set of quests before you, but some items can also have cons associated with them. The random outcomes of the doors you choose can have a heavy impact on whether or not you die or make it to the next floor. I noticed that the ranged classes usually survive longer due to being able to bottleneck enemies in doorways and blast them from the safety of a long hallway. Overall Hack, Slash, Loot is an update of an older vision of games long lost in a crowd of easy shooters and games that play themselves.

reviewText: Its pretty much a 8-bit version of D&D done by a real angry Dungeonmaster that wishes you to reroll every 5 to 10 seconds on most missions unless you play a mission with NPC helpers which seem to help but get in the way at the same time. I only got this as part of a Humble Bundle so I decided to give it a try and it is just too frustrating. The enemies seem to do as much if not no damage than you, and the worst part is that you don't level up like in a D&D game. So killing enemies is pointless unless you come across them, or for that rare occurance if you wish to duke one out for a piece of crappy gear which more likely than not will be a dowgrade rather than an upgrade. If the game had a leveling system for a reason to kill the enemies and a small party system where smart AI NPCs could play with you. Especially a spell system so you can cast spells to heal or kill enemies.\n\nSo long story short. This feels like a D&D game written poorly and could of done way better. If they make a second which I hope they do as a fix for this one. They will use some of the suggestions I listed even though I doubt they will read it. I was hoping for a fun 8-bit D&D clone and got this instead.

reviewText: I have a soft spot for ole text games like Mysteria, which makes me really like Hack, Slash, Loot. The overall setting of the game can be changed with the quest in the beginning of the game, although you have the option of choosing your class and quest on the title screen you also have the awesome option of setting it all to random making your next quest and class a surprise. The mechanics of the game are somewhat light although the big picture of the game is to stay alive and make smart choices when it comes to battling monsters and maintaining your health points. The armor weapons and items you find in game offer tons of support and help you best the set of quests before you, but some items can also have cons associated with them. The random outcomes of the doors you choose can have a heavy impact on whether or not you die or make it to the next floor. I noticed that the ranged classes usually survive longer due to being able to bottleneck enemies in doorways and blast them from the safety of a long hallway. Overall Hack, Slash, Loot is an update of an older vision of games long lost in a crowd of easy shooters and games that play themselves.

reviewText:
I'm very fond of HSL, so I wish I could recommend this game more highly. Its appealingly nostalgic looking, fairly accessible, and charmingly simple - cutting back on a lot of roguelike conventions without losing the main idea. Looting and getting stronger is predictably addictive.

Unfortunately it still feels unpolished and balanced poorly, and the worst offender is the fact that there are just relatively few meaningful actions for the player to consider and take throughout a playthrough. Questions a player faces are two: whether or not to engage, or whether or not to equip - and the answers to those questions are often strikingly obvious. I also haven't found a single practical reason yet to focus on melee over ranged weaponry. That fact combined with a relatively common boost makes the experience very simple to game.

In some was HSL feels like an iOS casual game, with a veneer of hardcore trappings, minus the in-app purchases. But I am fond of it, and will keep playing a bit.

reviewText:
This Game is honestly a bit of a dissapointment (probably more so if you got it for full price, I got it from a humble bundle). It looks like it should be a nice game, and while it does have its charm, but just not enough to make up for its flaws.

PROS:
-A number of artifacts, once you find one, you can choose to start with that artifact in any future game.
-A nice weapon/armor material system, silver weapons disarm foes, gold weapons give you stat bonuses occasionally, psychic weapons causes stat drain, among other things
-A couple of nice references to other (better) games in the form of some artifacts and uncommon rooms (such as an Aperture test chamber and I'm pretty sure I saw the castle crashers knights once)
-Despite not having an inventory (kind of a good thing, to be honest-it leads to less of the hoarding mentality many RPGs end up with) it does have a secondary weapon slot, and you can switch between the two easily, which I thought was a nice little feature.

CONS:
-Melee is awful-seriously, there's almost no reason to use it.
-combat is dull and repetetive (there's literally nothing beyond 'attack' and 'move')
-more than one or two friendly NPCs completely bog down the pace of the game
-Unlocking more characters seems to be completely random
-Death is frequent, not because the game is hard, but because healing is almost exclusively availible from random potions/scrolls/food (and the occasional vampiric weapon) and there's no garauntee you'll find anything that actually works well with your main combat stat. also poison is effectively incurable-if you can't survive until it passes on its own, you're dead.


While the game is flawed, it's still somewhat enjoyable if you stay away from the melee characters and the Battle for Stormrise quest. Playing as a Pixie Mage wearing plate armor and using a gun to shoot weapons out of your enemies hands is hard not to enjoy.

reviewText:
Time Played: 23 Hours
100% Achievements

Hack Slash Loot is an interesting attempt on the roguelike genre but has several flaws which make it great. Roguelikes have been traditionally difficult and reward intelligent player decisions, which gives players that sense of accomplishment after progression. But here, skill is pretty much a nonfactor with the only elements present being Don't get surrounded" or "Use elements enemies are weak to".

RNG will completely screw you over. It is entirely possible to die to the very first enemy you encounter. Hit chances are also extremely low in the beginning. Expect Miss-Miss-Hit-Miss-Hit every time you fight.

Another needlessly frustrating problem for the player is that there is no way to gain health other than by drinking random potions and hoping for the best (or gaining the op skill of regeneration).

Overall
date: a decent game but with all these problems
recommended:
it belongs in a mixed rating rather than yes/no.

Pros
Gets better after unlocking a few classes

Cons
Frustrating to progress
Die to RNG"

reviewText:
*shakes head sadly*  Such a pity.

Look, I like roguelikes.  I really do.  I've played a good few, and I enjoy a desperate struggle with limited resources, where every choice matters and one bad move can ruin an entire run.  I like to have to make hard decisions and cheat death through careful planning, frantic improvisation and the rare lucky break.

Hack Slash Loot is the antithesis of those things.

Unless the game has undergone a  total makeover in terms of design since I last played it, it's a broken, pointless roguelike in which you stand absolutely no chance in hell of surviving (unless you get lucky and get a Holy/Virtue element weapon that boosts your stats with each hit, right at the start of your run).

The most potent strategy you have is Stand in front of a doorway to fight the enemies one on one
date:
and pray that the guys stuck behind the guy you're hitting don't loop around and flank you before you kill them all one at a time".  You can't even RUN.  The enemies chase you forever like homing missiles and will not stop until you've bopped them on the head enough to kill them.  There's no class-specific skills to use and manage either.  It's all about the items you find and pick up.  And getting them?  Random.  There are virtually no hard choices in the game.  Just roll the dice and pray you make it.

It's like playing russian roulette with a fully loaded gun.  There is no skill.  Only luck.  Winning (Or even PROGRESS) is impossible unless you get insanely lucky.

If you want a roguelike
recommended: go play FTL (a much better game)
voteText: if you want an action-based roguelike
helpfulPercent: Eldritch is pretty good and actually takes skills and quick thinking to beat.  Go play those or the many other good roguelikes out there.  Avoid hack slash loot at all costs."

reviewText:
This feels like the most watered-down rogue-like experience ever. There's definitely a very good randomly-generated element to it, with randomly generated maps, enemy placements, loot, etc. What kills it for me, however, is the fact that there is barely anything to do in terms of combat -- there are three damage types (magic, melee, ranged), but the magic and ranged attacks play out identically in that they both have ranged attacks compared to melee's 1-tile range. In essence, it feels like the only reason there are ranged and magic damage types is so that the randomly generated loot isn't a coin flip to see if it's relevant to you or not.

I haven't seen anything resembling skills or abilities (though there are evidently artifacts that you can unlock once you beat a small campaign, allowing for better starting stats), so combat is literally just rolling the dice to see who hits and who doesn't with no room for any other options. As a result, playing with line of sight to minimize the amount of ranged attacks that can hit you during combat is the closest thing to tactics you'd have to employ. Inevitably, at many points in the game, you'll just spend many turns clicking on the same tile down a bottleneck, which is about as degenerate of an experience as I can imagine. Given how wild the RNG can be with the combat, sometimes even this much planning is not enough to do well, as enemies can hit devastatingly hard and your character's ~60% to hit does not perform as consistently as it would have you believe.

If you want a fantasy dice-rolling simulator, look no further. If you wanted something interactive or exciting, there are many better options out there.

reviewText:
I have put an embarassing amount of time into this little rogue-like-lite gem.

First the bad:

The graphics are embarassingly bad, with teeny sprites that have no animations.

For some reason, the console, which tells you crucial information about things happening around you, is obscured behind the map itself.

One or two glitches occur when continuing an earlier game, including torches blinking between torch and blood spot sprites.

The sound fits into the style of the game well, but it all sounds like someone cranked it out on sfxr in about 30 minutes or so.

Now the good:

The gameplay is both extremely simple and very deep.

The game has a ton of classes and artifacts to unlock, which will keep you coming back for more.

The gameplay is both fun and addicting.

This game is pretty difficult when you start out, and requires practice to improve at it.

You can pick this game up, play it for 30 minutes, and lay it back down without getting lost.

reviewText: Yeah... There's no experience points or levels in this game. It's all based on the loot you find. There's no inventory other than what your character has equipped, so everything you carry is based on swapping items. You can't carry healing potions or scrolls, so healing is based on finding the items. The constant 'stand-off' of enemies is annoying. It gets boring very quick.\n\nTo even call this game 'roguelike' is extremely insulting to the original. Do not recommend this game at all. Not worth $6.99. Wish I could get my money back.

reviewText:
Hack Slash Loot è un RPG puro, difficile ed estremamente longevo.

Pensato per essere realmente guidato dal fato e in minima parte dall'abilità delle proprie doti di giocatori, si può fare ben poco quando si beve la pozione sbagliata che disincanta tutti i propri oggetti magici, tuttavia ci si può trasformare in una macchina da guerra se le cose girano dalla nostra parte.

Nonostante l'apparente randomicità, il gameplay è del classico RPG per eccellenza, a turni e senza dare vantaggi a nessuno, ne a noi ne ai nemici.

Il gioco parte con personaggi deboli che moriranno senza scampo su tutti i livelli disponibili, poi man mano che moriremo, si sbloccheranno personaggi decisamente più interessanti come l'amazzone, probabilmente il personaggio più facile e potente da usare di tutto il gioco.

Se vi piace il genere puro RPG questo è un must, deve anche interessarvi poco la grafica, o almeno essere abbastanza vecchi da godervi un gioco a 8-bit in tutto il suo disarmante e scarno splendore.

PROS
- Puro RPG
- Immediato e semplice
- È come mangiare le patatine fritte, quando parti non riesci a fermarti
- Nonostante la disarmante semplicità grafica riesce ad essere vario
- Lo stile visuale è coerente e molto consistente

CONS
- Morire contro il mostro di fine quest, dopo 2-3 ore di gioco capita, spesso
- Morire contro un nemico a caso dopo molto impegno capita, spesso
- Frustranti capovolgimenti durante la partita
- Ci stava poter guidare più personaggi nella stessa partita
- Si sente la mancanza di uno story mode più profondo

Nonostante l'apparente randomicità, il gameplay è del classico RPG per eccellenza, a turni e senza dare vantaggi a nessuno, ne a noi ne ai nemici.

Il gioco parte con personaggi deboli che moriranno senza scampo su tutti i livelli disponibili, poi man mano che moriremo, si sbloccheranno personaggi decisamente più interessanti come l'amazzone, probabilmente il personaggio più facile e potente da usare di tutto il gioco.

Se vi piace il genere puro RPG questo è un must, deve anche interessarvi poco la grafica, o almeno essere abbastanza vecchi da godervi un gioco a 8-bit in tutto il suo disarmante e scarno splendore.

PROS
- Puro RPG
- Immediato e semplice
- È come mangiare le patatine fritte, quando parti non riesci a fermarti
- Nonostante la disarmante semplicità grafica riesce ad essere vario
- Lo stile visuale è coerente e molto consistente

CONS
- Morire contro il mostro di fine quest, dopo 2-3 ore di gioco capita, spesso
- Morire contro un nemico a caso dopo molto impegno capita, spesso
- Frustranti capovolgimenti durante la partita
- Ci stava poter guidare più personaggi nella stessa partita
- Si sente la mancanza di uno story mode più profondo

reviewText:
I have put an embarassing amount of time into this little rogue-like-lite gem.

First the bad:

The graphics are embarassingly bad, with teeny sprites that have no animations.

For some reason, the console, which tells you crucial information about things happening around you, is obscured behind the map itself.

One or two glitches occur when continuing an earlier game, including torches blinking between torch and blood spot sprites.

The sound fits into the style of the game well, but it all sounds like someone cranked it out on sfxr in about 30 minutes or so.

Now the good:

The gameplay is both extremely simple and very deep.

The game has a ton of classes and artifacts to unlock, which will keep you coming back for more.

The gameplay is both fun and addicting.

This game is pretty difficult when you start out, and requires practice to improve at it.

You can pick this game up, play it for 30 minutes, and lay it back down without getting lost.

reviewText:
Hack, Slash, Loot: Not, Very, Good

There have been multiple occasions wherein I have tried to play Hack, Slash, Loot. Both times didn’t last very long… As you can tell by my total play time of an hour. I’m just gonna be straight and say I don’t like this game. But the fact that I’m reviewing it after an hour should be more than enough evidence of that.

The main issues I have with Hack, Slash, Loot stem from the fact that it is based entirely around luck, it’s rather shallow, and frankly it’s just unengaging. Also I wanted to play it more, but it’s now continuously crashing; thus preventing me from even giving the game another chance. It’s almost as if the game knows I’m not fond of it and it’s hiding from further examination!

Crashing aside Hack, Slash, Loot definitely has some cool ideas, but the game’s execution could definitely have used some work. When the game launches, after you’ve taken about five minutes to parse the UI, you can pick from a rather large selection of quests-- these are essentially the game’s ‘campaigns’; and four character classes. The game’s various quests are really just a set of parameters on the random dungeon generation. Apparently the dungeons span multiple floors and also contain bosses but I’ve never lived long enough to see one…

This is because the game pits you off against a nearly unending horde of monsters that do far too much damage, have way too much health, and almost comically out number you. Plus healing items are few and far between due to the random nature of the game’s loot. In the hour I’ve played I’ve probably run through thirty or forty dungeons.

Let that sink in.

My longest run was probably 20 minutes, and I still never made it past the first floor. Hell, I’ve died in the room that I spawned in.

Fighting hordes of powerful enemies can definitely be fun, other games prove this. But Hack, Slash, Loot’s reliance on luck permeates into the combat as well. Even with a 60% chance to hit I find myself missing the majority of my shots. A fight with a single monster can take upwards of ten turns or more, which are spent watching your character and the monster haplessly flail at one another only occasionally connecting. Once you finally land a hit and damage to the monster you have to hope that you roll well... or you’ll find yourself dealing almost no damage, making the fight take even longer.

There’s nothing like missing ten attacks only to land one and deal 2 damage.

The best way I can describe this game is that it feels like a Pen and Paper RPG, like Pathfinder… But without any of the systems that actually allow you to do the cool stuff.

There are no modifiers that help your dice rolls, or give you an edge. It’s just raw randomness.

Most of the time you simply rely on luck, and hope that the five orcs breathing down your neck miss more than you do. Or that you get a good weapon that can deal decent damage. But that only happened to me once, and then I promptly died.

This game definitely has potential. And it’s clearly there under the layers of randomness… But  as it stands Hack, Slash, Loot isn’t worth your time.

reviewText: This game looks to be a traditional rogue like, but only offer three-ish classes that don't even cover the basic trinity (knight, rogue, mage). People complain about RNG, but honestly thats just part of the game. My main issues with the game were the complete lack of a list of controls or menu system. You have to learn the controls from an external website, there is no way of learning them in game. The diaglogue systemis clunky and only displays the past 3 actions. If you want a more indepth much more varied rogue like try Stone soup. Google it. Its completely free, much more complex and in depth, and personally much more fun. Avoid this.
